canonical_explanation.text: Simple machines are devices that make work easier by changing the direction or amount of force needed. There are six types of simple machines: lever, pulley, wheel and axle, inclined plane, wedge, and screw. A lever is a rod that rotates around a fixed point called the fulcrum (examples: see-saw, scissors, bottle opener). An inclined plane is a sloped surface that makes it easier to move objects up or down (examples: ramps, slides). A wedge is like two inclined planes joined together and is used for cutting or splitting (examples: knife, axe, nail). A pulley is a wheel with a rope that helps lift heavy objects (examples: flagpole, well). A wheel and axle is a wheel attached to a rod and helps move or turn things (examples: door knob, steering wheel). A screw is an inclined plane wrapped around a cylinder and is used for holding things together (examples: screws, jar lids).
rules: Six simple machines: lever, pulley, wheel and axle, inclined plane, wedge, screw
Lever: rod rotating around a fixed point (fulcrum)
Lever examples: see-saw, scissors, bottle opener, pliers
Inclined plane: sloped surface for easier movement
Inclined plane examples: ramps, slides, sloping roads
Wedge: two inclined planes joined, used for cutting/splitting
Wedge examples: knife, axe, nail, chisel
Pulley: wheel with rope for lifting
Wheel and axle: wheel attached to rod
Wheel and axle examples: door knob, steering wheel, screwdriver
Screw: inclined plane wrapped around cylinder
Screw examples: screws, jar lids, light bulbs
